Literature Review: SMC (Structural Maintenance of Chromosomes) complexes are essential components of the cellular machinery responsible for maintaining chromosomal integrity and organization. These complexes, which include cohesin and condensin, are highly conserved across eukaryotes and play crucial roles in various aspects of chromosome biology, including sister chromatid cohesion, chromosome condensation, and the formation of topologically associating domains (TADs) (Nasmyth, 2001; Haering et al., 2008). The ability of SMC complexes to form and maintain DNA loops is a fundamental aspect of their function, and recent advances in single-molecule techniques have provided unprecedented insights into the mechanisms underlying this process. Recent studies have elucidated the structural and functional properties of SMC complexes, highlighting their role in DNA loop extrusion. Single-molecule assays have revealed that cohesin and condensin can actively extrude DNA loops in vitro, suggesting a conserved mechanism for genome organization (Ganji et al., 2018; Kim et al., 2019). These experiments have shown that SMC complexes can translocate along DNA, forming loops by capturing and pulling DNA segments through their central ring structure (Terakawa et al., 2017). This process is energy-dependent and involves the hydrolysis of ATP, which drives the conformational changes necessary for DNA translocation (Nuebler et al., 2018). The biophysical properties of SMC complexes have been further characterized using high-resolution imaging techniques. For instance, super-resolution microscopy has allowed researchers to visualize the dynamic behavior of cohesin and condensin on chromatin in living cells (Gibcus et al., 2018). These studies have demonstrated that SMC complexes exhibit rapid binding and unbinding kinetics, which is consistent with their role in dynamic genome organization. Additionally, the use of optical tweezers has provided direct measurements of the forces generated by SMC complexes during DNA loop extrusion, revealing that these complexes can exert significant tension on DNA (Terakawa et al., 2017). Despite these advances, several questions remain regarding the precise mechanisms of DNA loop extrusion by SMC complexes. One area of active investigation is the regulation of SMC complex activity. It is known that accessory factors, such as NIPBL and WAPL, play critical roles in modulating the loading and unloading of cohesin onto chromatin (Gerlich et al., 2006; Watrin et al., 2006). Recent studies have also identified specific post-translational modifications that can influence the function of SMC complexes, suggesting that these modifications may serve as regulatory switches (Hirano, 2016). Another important aspect of SMC complex function is their role in the establishment and maintenance of TADs. TADs are genomic regions that are thought to represent the basic units of chromosome organization, and they are often flanked by boundary elements that prevent the mixing of chromatin from adjacent domains (Dixon et al., 2012). Single-molecule studies have provided evidence that SMC complexes can form loops that correspond to TAD boundaries, suggesting that these complexes are directly involved in the formation of TADs (Rao et al., 2014). However, the exact mechanisms by which SMC complexes recognize and bind to these boundary elements remain to be fully understood. In addition to their role in chromosome organization, SMC complexes are also involved in the regulation of gene expression. For example, cohesin has been shown to facilitate long-range interactions between enhancers and promoters, which are essential for the proper regulation of gene expression (Kagey et al., 2010). Condensin, on the other hand, is known to promote the compaction of chromatin, which can repress gene expression (Hirano, 2016). These findings highlight the multifaceted nature of SMC complex function and underscore the importance of understanding the interplay between genome organization and gene regulation. The study of SMC complexes has also shed light on the pathophysiology of certain diseases. Mutations in genes encoding SMC complex subunits or their regulatory factors have been linked to a variety of human disorders, including developmental abnormalities and cancer (Schmidt et al., 2015). For instance, mutations in the cohesin subunit SMC1A have been associated with Cornelia de Lange syndrome, a condition characterized by growth retardation and intellectual disability (Deardorff et al., 2012). Similarly, alterations in condensin function have been implicated in the development of chromosomal instability, a hallmark of many cancers (Hirano, 2016). In conclusion, the study of SMC complexes has significantly advanced our understanding of chromosome biology and genome organization. Single-molecule studies have provided valuable insights into the mechanisms of DNA loop extrusion, while genetic and biochemical approaches have elucidated the regulatory networks that control SMC complex function. Future research will likely continue to uncover new aspects of SMC complex biology, furthering our knowledge of how these essential proteins contribute to the maintenance and regulation of the genome.
